titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Wednesday.

Mr Gales sent this morning for the manuscript of my Speech last week on the Resolution for granting Rations to the fugitives from Indian hostilities in Alabama and Georgia, and I sent it to him for publication in the Intelligencer to-morrow, having just then finished writing it out— Dr Laurie came to me with a very affecting Letter requesting a loan of 250 dollars, which I made— Mrs Ann Adams went with me to judge Cranch’s house for a visit to take leave there, and I went to the House— There a motion was made by Heister to suspend the Rules to take up the Resolution from the Senate for adjourning Congress on the 23d. of May. he said that he wished to propose the 27th. of this Month for the day of adjournment— Motion was made to lay the motion to suspend on the table—rejected— Then the motion to suspend was rejected 91 to 82— Then Hiram P. Hunt asked leave to make a statement of personal concern to himself—objected to. but the rule was suspended 126 to 36— Hunt’s complaint was that a pamphlet report of H. L. Pinckney’s Slavery committee had been published by the printers of the Globe in which the yeas and nays on the first Resolution of the Slavery Committee, and his name was recorded as voting for the Resolution, when he had really voted against it—and that great multitudes of these spurious publications have been scattered all over the Country, by franks of members of Congress— Claiborne of Mississippi and other members asked leave also to make Statements; but were refused— The Bill for the reorganization of the Post-Office Department was debated, till the Previous Question was applied and it passed to be engrossed for a third reading— I took some part in this debate; especially concerning the Salaries of the Officers. The Annual Post-route Bill followed, and after some amendments, passed without opposition to the third reading. Adjourned before seven O’Clock— Mr and Mrs Abbott Lawrence with their daughter paid us an Evening visit. A North-eastern storm, is now at its eighth day, and we have a fire daily in our dining-room.
2. V. Thursday.

My Speech on the distribution of rations to the fugitives from Indian hostilities in Alabama and Georgia was published in the National Intelligencer of this morning, and a subscription paper was circulated in the House for printing it in a pamphlet, for which Gales told me there were 2500 copies ordered— Several members of the House of both parties spoke of it to me; some with strong dissent— After the reading of the Journal several propositions for the receipt of petitions—and several by consent were received. G. Lee offered a Resolution to which I objected unless the House would allow me to present twenty Petitions remonstrances and memorials against the admission of Arkansas, as a Slave State— The Bill for reorganizing the Post-Office Department— Henry Johnson moved to recommit the Bill to the Committee of the whole Union, with Instructions to strike out the 43d. and 44th. Sections— Cutting off the perquisite of the private Letter-boxes— Then after a three hours debate, Speight moved the Previous Question and the Bill was passed— The Bill for establishing new Post-routes was next read and passed—while it was reading I went into the Senate, and agreed with Mr Clay, that the Committees of Conference on the Spanish Convention Bill, shall meet in a Committee room of the Senate at Noon to-morrow— In the House, the Amendments of the Senate to the Indian annuity Bill were reconsidered in Committee of the whole on the Union, and debated, till 5 O’Clock when the Committee rose— I moved to take up the Resolution for printing an extra number of H. L. Pinckney’s Slavery Report with the proceedings of the House upon it; but there was hardly a Quorum in the House and they adjourned. Mrs W. S. Smith spent the Evening here— Mrs. Angier is still confined to her chamber—
3. V. Friday

I was detained at home this morning so that it was close upon 11. O’Clock when I reached the House— They were engaged upon a Bill just received from the Senate changing the time of the annual meeting of Congress—to the first Monday of November, and providing that the first Session of each Congress shall close on the first Monday of May— After some debate the previous question was carried on the passage of the Bill to a third reading, for which I voted— And I then moved that the Bill should be referred to a select Committee with Instructions to strike out that part of it which relates to the time of closing the Sessions in May— This introduced a debate during which I went with the Conferees of the House to meet the conferees of the Senate upon the disagreeing votes of the two Houses, on the Bill for carrying into execution the Convention with Spain. We met in the Committee Room, of the Judiciary Committee of the Senate— The conferees of the Senate were H. Clay, Alexander Porter and William R. King— Those of the House, were John Y. Mason,Judson, John Cramer, and Benjamin Hardin, with myself as Chairman— After a short conversation, the two Committees agreed, that there should be one Commissioner instead of three; but not the Attorney General. one or two other slight modifications of the Bill were also agreed upon— The Papers being with the Senate, Mr Clay promised to draw up the report, according to the agreement, and to communicate it to me. In a quarter of an hour we were agreed, and Hardin came in just as we were separating— On returning to the House I found the joint resolution fixing the annual Meeting of Congress on the first Monday in November had passed as it came from the Senate, by the Previous Question— The Indian annuity Bill, with the amendments of the Senate, was debated by J. Bell, Horace Everett—Joseph M. White, Lewis and Lawler of Alabama, Vinton, Glascock and myself, till near six, when the Committee rose, and the House adjourned—
4. V. Saturday

Mrs Ann Adams went last Evening to Mr W. S. Smith’s— Mrs Angier and Mary went with me to the Capitol. It was half past ten, and the House was taking the yeas and nays on the question of a call of the House, which was rejected— Motion was made to suspend the rules to take up the Resolution from the Senate fixing the day of Adjournment of this Session 102 to 88. Not two thirds— Cambreleng moved to suspend the rules to take up the Fortification Bill—after motions to amend by including the Bill for continuing the Cumberland road; and the Bills for admitting his States of Michigan and Arkansas into the Union, which were rejected, the vote was against suspending the rules— Private Business was taken up; and after the Previous Question the Pea patch Bill was laid on the table by vote 94 to 82— Mr Clay came into the House, with the Report of the Committees of Conference, on the Bill for carrying into execution the Convention with Spain; conformably to the agreement between the two Committees yesterday. They were both signed by him, and I signed them— He took one of them back with him, and left one with me— Soon after, the Secretary of the Senate came in, with the Bill passed by the Senate, conformably to the agreement— I then presented to the House the Report from the Committee of Conference, which was read. I moved that the Bill as passed in the Senate should be immediately considered, and it passed by unanimous consent. Private business was resumed an the Quorum soon disappeared from the House— A debate arose upon some question upon a grant of lands, and about 3. O’Clock the House adjourned. Mr Heman Lincoln called me out of the House, and I had with him a short conversation— He resides at Cambridge, and is about 8 days from home— He leaves the City this afternoon on his return. I walked home with L. Jarvis— Mrs Ann Adams came this Evening back from Mr W. S. Smith’s. I received this morning a Letter from my Son Charles which I immediately answered.
5. V. Sunday

I went with Mrs. Ann Adams, and my Grandchild Mary Louisa, to the Unitarian Church this morning and heard MrFox of Newbury-Port preach from Mark 4.26. “And he said, So is the kingdom of God, as if a man should cast seed into the ground. 27. And should sleep and rise, night and day, and the seed should spring and grow up, he knoweth not how. 28. For the earth bringeth forth fruit of herself; first the blade, then the ear, after that the full corn in the ear.” Mr Fox is settled as the Successor of Dr John Andrews, in the Parish at Newbury-Port, where I attended public worship when I was a student there— Mr Fox is one of the fruits of the new Unitarian theological school at Cambridge— They are teachers of morals—Christian Morals— But not Christian Metaphysics, nor Christian Fables— Now this is a difficult thing. To take the morals, without the metaphysics and without the Fables. Mr Fox however descanted sometime on the power of the Parables of Jesus Christ, and this perhaps cannot be too highly estimated— The Sermon itself was moderate, dispassionate and sensible— Mr Smith came home with us and paid a short visit— After dinner I attended at the Presbyterian Church, and heard a Mr Elliot, from Philippians 1.27— “Only let your Conversation be, as it becometh the Gospel of Christ.”— The tone and style of discourse varied much from that of Mr Fox in the morning— Mr Elliot gave notice that there would be on Tuesday afternoon a meeting of the Church and Society, to choose a Pastor— Mr James H. Hammond, a member of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina, is going to Europe for his health which is much impaired. His Colleague Waddy Thompson, asked me some days since if I could give Letters of introduction to Mr Hammond, to any of my acquaintance at London or Paris— I wrote this afternoon accordingly Letters to George La Fayette, and to Daniel Brent, at Paris, and to Coll. Aspinwall our Consul at London— I made out also a list of the Memorials and remonstrances against the Article concerning Slavery in the Constitution of Arkansas, which I shall attempt to present to-morrow.
6. V. Monday

At the House the first subject taken up was the Resolutions of the Legislature of Maryland in favour of the distribution of the proceeds of the Sales of the public Lands among the States, and of expunging the Resolutions of the Senate against the . . ., upon which Thomas of Maryland claimed the floor— I asked him to suspend his remarks to give an opportunity for the presentation of Petitions but he declined— He then made a Speech of about an hour in answer to the Attack upon him by Jenifer, on the 24th. of last Month; and Jenifer replied—this was a second edition of their former altercation— Near noon the Maryland Resolutions were laid on the table, and the States and Territories were called over for Petitions and Memorials— I presented twenty-two Memorials and Remonstrances against the admission of Arkansas into the Union as a Slave State, and against the Article in the Constitution of that State respecting Slavery—they were all laid on the table, by the Resolution of the 25th. of May— I presented also two other Petitions, which were referred one to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, and the other to the Committee on the judiciary— There were a multitude of other Petitions, against the Slavery Article in the Constitution of Arkansas—all laid on the table without debate— Sevier offered a Resolution to make the Bill to fix the Northern boundary of Ohio, and the Bills for the admission of Michigan and Arkansas for Wednesday and following days, which was carried by vote of more than two thirds— The Indian annuity Bill was then carried through the Committee of the whole, and to the third reading. Sundry other Bills also passed in Committee of the whole. Mrs A. Adams and Mrs Angier visited the President this morning and with Joseph left the city this afternoon—
7. V. Tuesday

I received yesterday morning a Letter from William Otis, written in the Prison of this City, enclosing a Letter to the Speaker Polk, and a Petition to both Houses of Congress to issue an order to bring him bodily before them to state his claims upon the public Treasury. In his Letter to me he asked my advice, and expressed a wish that I would visit him in prison— I accordingly went this morning to the Prison, and had a conversation with him. I told him that his petition requested what neither house had power to grant—and described to him the kind of petition suited to his case, and promised if he would prepare such a petition to present it for him— At the House— Reports from Committees were received— Mann of New-York renewed his motion to suspend the rules, to offer a Resolution to fix a day for considering the Resolution from the Senate to adjourn Congress on the 23d. of May— I voted this time in favour of the motion; but there were not quite two thirds to support it— The question whether the Land Bill from the Senate (Mr Clay’s) should be referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union recurred. Yeas 97. nays 96. The Speaker voted in the negative 97 to 97. and the vote was not carried and therefore lost.— The next question of reference was to the Committee of Ways and Means—debated till one, when the order of the day was called— The fortification Bill— The question was upon striking out 150000 and inserting 200000 for the fortification of Charleston— Waddy Thompson made a Speech of an hour and a half in answer to a printed Speech of Towne and to my Speech of the 25th. of last Month. He was followed by Hiram P. Hunt of New-York in a speech of 2. hours—and then Townes replied to Waddy Thompson— Altercation between Townes and Thompson. Then Storer, moved to reduce the appropriations, and Kinnard the previous question. The debate continued, till the Bill was made the special order of the day for Friday after 11. O’Clock; and at 8 in the Evening the House adjourned.
8. V. Wednesday

At the House, the Bills for the fixing the Northern Boundary of Ohio and the Bills for the admission of Michigan and Arkansas into the Union as States,—the first Bill was that for fixing the Northern Boundary of the State of Ohio— Thomas from the Committee on the Judiciary moved to lay the Bill on the table, upon the ground that by the Bill for the admission of Michigan into the Union, the same provision was inserted, whereby the special Bill to fix the Northern boundary of Ohio, became superfluous. This gave rise to a sharp short debate in which the Ohio members and especially Vinton took a very heated part— Boon of Indiana sprung the previous question, before the Bill had even been read— The vote for seconding the previous question was 69 to 103.— Then further hot debate till the question upon laying the Bill upon the table was carried 103 to 103 and decided by the casting vote of the Speaker to the great annoyance of the Ohio members— The next Bill in order was the Michigan Bill, which Wise moved to postpone till next Monday, to take up first the Arkansas Bill; to make it sure that the Slave State shall first come in— Another fiery debate, Wise expressed a fear that a restriction upon Slavery would be proposed, and if adopted by the House, he said he would propose a section to introduce Slavery into Michigan. Mann and Vanderpoel gave a sort of promise that the proposition concerning Slavery, should be made in the debate on the Arkansas Bill— I said if no other member would offer such a proposal I would. A question then arose whether both Bills must be referred to the Committee of the whole, or not, as indirectly making a charge upon the People— The Speaker after much decided upon a precedent of 1832. decided that they must be referred to the Committee of the whole—the House immediately went into Committee on the Michigan Bill—
9. V. Thursday

Summer weather again. My Grandchildren rode with me to the Capitol. At the House sundry reports from Committees were received, and one or two Bills were passed— Hardin moved to take up the Bill fixing the Northern Boundary of Ohio, which was yesterday laid on the table— The Speaker decided that the unfinished business of yesterday was the Bill for fixing the boundary of Ohio and admitting Michigan as a State in the Union, and that the order of business by the rule of the House could be changed only by a vote of two thirds— Storer appealed from this decision, and argued that the unfinished business of the House was the three Bills which had been all made the special order of the day yesterday and that although the House laid one of the Bills on the table, and referred the two others to the Committee of the whole on the Union, yet what was done in Committee was not unfinished business of the House, and a mere majority might this day take up the Bill laid on the table yesterday, instead of that upon which the Committee debated yesterday— Storer finally withdrew his appeal, and the House went again into Committee of the whole on the Union, Speight in the Chair on the Bill fixing the northern Boundary of Ohio and for the admission of Michigan into the Union— Everett read a Speech, containing some few ideas of his own— He was followed by Howard and he by Love of New-York, who offered an Amendment which he intended to offer— I then spoke upon the amendment offered by Vinton, and was immediately followed by Corwin and Whittlesey (Bond had spoken before) then Pearce on the other side, and Vinton in reply— The debate continued till about midnight—all amendments were inflexibly rejected—the Bill was then laid aside, and the Bill for the admission of Arkansas was taken up—some trivial amendments were offered and rejected

about one O’Clock in the morning, twice successively, the Committee found itself without a Quorum— The first time, after sending for all the members in and about the capitol, a bare quorum was restored—and the Speaker left the Chair and Speight resumed it, without waiting for a vote of the House— The second time they could not make a quorum and were obliged to resort to a Call of the House which absorbed nearly four hours in its various stages till the absentees were brought in, in Custody of the Serjeant at Arms, and required to offer their excuses for absence— The first was C. F. Mercer one of the oldest and most laborious members of the House, whose excuses were an indignant rebuke of the House itself— Joseph Johnson of Virginia was the second and Hawes of Kentucky the third. On being asked by the Speaker what excuse he had to offer he said he did not know that he had any good excuse to give— The house voted to excuse him, and then to excuse all the rest— There were 81 absentees returned without excuse, and from twenty to thirty brought in under custody— Then the House resumed business, and the Speaker again left the Chair without motion or vote of the House, and Speight resumed it— I then at 5. In the morning offered my amendment to the 3d. Section of the Bill for the admission of Arkansas; it was very short and I said very little in presenting it—but it kindled a fiery debate, of three hours in which Wise, Cushing, Briggs, Hoare, Hard of New-York took a part and Dromgoole, drunk with whiskey and Bynum drunk with Slavery used insulting language, which I demanded should be taken down by the Clerk, but which Speight the chairman would not notice— My amendment was rejected by tellers 32 to 90. About 8 O’Clock Slade came in and offered a much stronger Amendment which was rejected— Underwood offered an amendment to the Michigan Bill which was rejected. Wise spoke till ten O’Clock when Chambers of Kentucky made a point of order whether the Speaker was not bound to take the Chair for this day— He would not. Wise spoke another hour— Then the Committee rose and reported the two Bills; and the house adjourned at 11. O’Clock— I rode home with S. C. Phillips— S. Sampson was here this Evening
11. V. Saturday.

Call at Mr. Abbott Lawrence’s lodgings and left there 100 copies of the Pamphlet on the Texas Insurrection which he had requested me to procure for him, and which I received this morning from Philadelphia. At the House while the Journal of Thursday was reading the Reporter for the Telegraph namedWheeler assailed with an iron, sharp pointed cane, the reporter for the Southern Patriot and struck at him as he sat in his Seat three times. Wheeler stood at the entrance of the Seat; and stepped up as he gave the strokes of the cane— Codd, the Southern Patriot Reporter, was cooped up in his Seat, from which he arose and held up his arm to guard his head. The Speaker instantly ordered the Serjeant at Arms to turn Wheeler out of the Hall, and to take him into custody, and a confused and desultory debate arose and a resolution was adopted directing that the two persons (without naming them) should be kept in custody of the Serjeant at arms, till further order— The debate was continued, and sundry proposals were made, till a Committee of five were appointed to consider and report to the House on the case— The remainder of the Journal was then read and I moved an amendment which after a paltering and equivocating debate was rejected by yeas and nays 32 to 133. The amendment was a rectification of a false Statement, that Hawes had been yesterday morning excused for reasons given by him, when in fact he declared that he had no good reason to give— The special order of this day was a multitude of Pension Bills, which were considered in Committee of the whole— Craig in the Chair a large number of them were reported to the house and passed to a third reading—several were however laid aside for discussion hereafter— Near five O’Clock the Committees appointed to examine the two men between whom the affray of the morning had passed, reported in part that Codd, the assaulted party should be forthwith discharged which was, unanimously agreed to—and Mann of New-York offered a Resolution that the Speaker do issue his warrant to the Serjeant at arms to arrest and detain Wheeler, and at my suggestion added the cause of the arrest—which Resolution was also adopted without opposition— House adjourned after 5. and I walked home, with rain.
12. V. Sunday

“Clouds and darkness are round about him: righteousness and judgment are the habitation of his throne.[”] Psalm 97.2 This was the text of the morning preacher at the Presbyterian Church—the same who preached there last Sunday afternoon— The text was impressive and the Discourse was well written, and was listened to with devout attention by the auditory— The preacher in his prayer disclosed the fact that there had been a unanimous election of a Minister by the Society: and he gave notice of a Lecture upon sacred music to be delivered next Wednesday Evening at Dr. Laurie’s Church— Mr and Mrs Frye and Thomas dined with us, but my dear wife was so much indisposed with a cough and sore breast that she could not go down— After dinner I attended again at the Presbyterian Church and heard a Dr Read of Savannah, Georgia from Romans 8.14. “For as many as are led, by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God.” This Discourse was delivered without Notes, but with much animation— It was an exhortation to spiritual Religion— One of his Hymns was the 65th. of the 2d. Book—When I can read my title clear, to mansions in the skies—a beautiful Ode— Mr Hassler called upon me this Evening; just recovering from a bilious fever, and with a frightful cough upon him— Still complaining that he cannot obtain from the Secretary of the Treasury adequate compensation for his Services. I wrote a certificate for Mr James Bigelow, concerning Grubb, Joseph B. Stuart, and the Casaux claim— Mr Bigelow had yesterday called me from my Seat in the House and requested this of me— It seems they have lost at the Treasury Department, my answer to Mr M’lane’s enquiries—and my Letter Book containing the copy of it is at Quincy.
13. V. Monday

Mr Bigelow called upon me this morning, and I read to him a certificate relating to the claim of Casaux and the Assignment of it to James Grubb, and Josephus B. Stuart, which he said would be sufficient for his purpose, and which, retaining it to be copied I promised to have with me at the House to-morrow morning—and to give to him there— At the House the first hour and a half was consumed in reading and passing the Pension Bills, which had been ordered to be engrossed on Saturday— Miller of Pennsylvania moved to have them all read by their titles and passed into a lump; to which I objected and they were all read— About half past eleven the orders of the day was called— The act fixing the Northern boundary of the State of Ohio, and admitting conditionally the State of Michigan into the Union— Vinton moved his amendment which had been rejected in Committee of the whole; and as I saw the Previous Question was coming I sent my proposed Amendment to the Speaker and offered it as an Amendment to Vinton’s amendment— The Speaker said it was not in order, as an amendment to the Amendment; but that I might offer it as an amendment to the Bill— Vinton merely asked the yeas and nays on his amendment which was rejectedI then offered my amendment, and while I was offering it a member rose to move the Previous question; but I had the floor and supported my amendment in a speech of three hours, interrupted occasionally by Thomas, Howard and Hamer of Ohio— The instant I sat down, Cushman of New Hampshire moved the Previous Question, which was carried, and the Bill passed to the third reading by yeas and naysThen followed the Bill for the admission of Arkansas—upon which I offered the Amendment, I had proposed in Committee of the whole— It was read, and I remained on my feet to address the House in support of it— Williams of Kentucky started up and moved the previous Question— I claimed the floor and the Speaker gave it to me— Williams insisted on his right to it, and the Speaker gave it to him— I appealed from the decision, and the House sustained the Speaker by a vote of 97 to 87. the Previous Question was carried— The Bill passed to a third reading bytoBoth Bills were passed without amendment by the Previous Question— Adjourned about 6.— Met the Barouche with my wife and Mary and rode home with them—
14. V. Tuesday

Two young men, friends from Philadelphia brought me a Letter of Introduction from Benjamin Lundy—and had some conversation with me— I was quite unwell, and twice up in the Night, and by consequence, was belated at the House— At half past ten, I found they were taking the yeas and nays on a motion to suspend the rules to take up the joint Resolution from the Senate, for the adjournment of Congress on the 23d of May— The motion prevailed, and the joint Resolution was debated about two hours— Heister first moved the 27th. of June and afterwards modified to the 4th. of July—the 11th. and the 2d of July were proposed; and a proposition was also made to refer the Resolution to a Committee, consisting of the chairmen of all the standing Committees, to consider what business should be done before the close of the Session, and recommend to the House a day for that purpose—finally the motion to adjourn on the 11th. of July, was taken by yeas and nays and rejected, and then the 4th. of July was fixed for the day without yeas and nays, order of the day—the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, on a bill Supplementary to the Act admitting Arkansas into the Union, the Bill Supplementary to the Michigan act of admission; and a Bill establishing a judicial district in Michigan, Franklin Pierce in the Chair. The Bill supplementary to the admission of Arkansas was first taken up. Vinton moved an amendment to reject the 8th. proposition of the Convention of Arkansas, which formed their Constitution; which was debated till between three and four O’Clock— Sevier the delegate from Arkansas after most pertinaciously struggling against it finally acceded to it, and it was adopted— A similar amendment was adopted to the Michigan Admission supplementary Bill, and they together with the Bill for extending the Laws of the United States over the State of Michigan— The Bills passed to the third reading, and about 5. O’Clock the House adjourned— Walk home with Mr Jarvis— Mr Frye was at my house this Evening, and I gave him a check for my taxes 290:32— Bynum and Jenifer fought their duel this morning. six shots exchanged, and no harm done— Pickens was Jenifer’s second, and Sevier Bynum’s. Bynum fired his sixth shot before the word of command—and thus by the duello, put himself upon the Mercy of his adversary.
15. V. Wednesday

I obtained a copy of the original draught of the Journal of the day before yesterday with the erasures and alterations in it and after the reading this morning of the Journal of the day before yesterday, I moved that the Journal of the day before, be made to read as it had already been drawn up by the assistant Clerk—this occasioned a debate of an hour which was first abridged by a motion to lay my motion for amendment on the table, but this was immediately withdrawn, and the previous question was substituted for it and carried, and my amendment was rejected by yeas and nays— Ingersoll then moved the suspension of the rules to take up a Resolution for supplying the new Members of the present Congress with certain books which have been received by the members of former Congresses— The Rules were suspended by a vote of more than two thirds, and then the Resolution was driven through by the previous question; and after it was passed they began to think that some of the Books were out of print, and could not be distributed, without the expense of a reprint. exceptions were moved.— I moved a reconsideration of the vote that the question should be now put— The hour for which the rules were suspended passed away—an attempt to suspend them again failed for want of the two thirds— The Supplementary Michigan and Arkansas Bills were passed; and the Bill for establishing a judicial district in Michigan was at the third reading, when it was discovered that the Salary in the engrossed Bill remained at 2000 dollars, though by an amendment yesterday adopted it had been reduced to 1500—of which amendment there was no notice on the Journal— I suggested that while they were making this amendment they might consider whether another might not be expedient—a proviso that the Bill should not take effect until Michigan should be admitted into the Union— Bond said he had thought of that and moved the proviso which was adopted— The Ohio Boundary Bill, was then forced through— Anthony and Miller and Wardwell declaring against it. Underwood answered one of my arguments, to which Briggs and I replied. Previous Question and the Bill passed— The fortification Bill then came up—
16. V. Thursday

The children rode part of the way with me to the Capitol this morning. After the reading of the Journal Mr Judson, Chairman of the Select Committee on the assault by H. G. Wheeler on the person of Robert Codd last Saturday, called up their Report for consideration.— The Committee reported three Resolutions 1. That Wheeler by the assault upon Codd, in the Hall while the House was in Session had been guilty of a contempt and violation of the privileges of the House— 2. That he should be excluded from the Reporter’s seat and any other place within the Hall, hereafter. 3. That he should be imprisoned in custody of the Serjeant at Arms, for the remainder of the Session. The House were beginning to discuss the Resolutions, when at the motion of Heister, the Serjeant at arms was ordered to bring Wheeler to the Bar of the House which he did— After several proposals of Amendments were rejected, the first Resolution of the Committee was adopted— The second with a qualification till the end of the present Session, and instead of the third a Resolution to discharge him from custody which was forthwith done— Abijah Mann, was alone to insist upon his imprisonment for the remainder of the Session— But his argument was hooted out of the House— The Bill for distributing the proceeds of the Sales of the Public Lands, was first in order with an unsettled question to what Committee it should be referred. Ways and Means, Public Lands, or a Select Committee with instructions to report the Bill without amendment, a wrangling disputation of amendments then succeeded; and Speight moved as a test question to lay the Bill on the table. Call of the House 206 members answered to their names— The vote to lay the Bill on the table was lost 96 to 110— Then the amendment process recommenced, till one O’Clock when the fortification bill, became the special order of the day— The amendment reported by the Committee of the whole, increasing the item for the fortification in Charleston Harbour South Carolina
from 150000 to 200000 was lost on the yeas and nays, by a vote of 95 to 98— Then a reconsideration was moved by Storer at the request of H. L. Pinckney, and lost bytoA subsequent item of the Appropriation Bill was then taken up, and Speight moved a Resolution to take a recess from half past two till four O’Clock this and every other day till the end of the Session— Objection made, he moved a suspension of the Rule, and carried it, and the Resolution— Accordingly there was a recess from half-past two till four, which I passed, writing in the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures— On returning to the Hall two minutes after four I found the Speaker in the Chair and the Clerk, calling the name of Ashley, upon a motion for a Call of the House— The vote was 47 ayes 48 noes— Whittlesey moved that it be ascertained whether a Quorum were not present— The Speaker said the assistant Clerk reported to him 124 members present— The fortification Bill was resumed and debated till between 8 and 9. O’Clock. the amendment reported by the Committee of the whole of 200000 dollars was at the motion of Hard of New-York after a snarling debate reduced to 100000. After which came the amendment of 700000 for arming the fortifications to which Cambreleng proposed a specifying amendment, and said if it should be rejected he would move to reduce the 700000 dollars to 450000 dollars— With this encouragement the opposition fell foul again of this amendment, and Graves of Kentucky moved to adjourn— The votes by Tellers were 76 to 75. and the Speaker announced that the House was adjourned. Jarvis with whom I walked home, thought that the Speaker ought to have voted against adjourning and produced a tie. In which case the adjournment would not have been carried— The Senate this afternoon passed to be engrossed a bill for regulating the deposit Banks, and for loaning to the States the surplus funds in the Treasury, to the great consternation of the Van Buren administration party— The vote in the Senate was forty to six—
17. V. Friday

The children rode with me to the Capitol. Heister moved a suspension of the Rules to move a Resolution to devote two hours of to-morrow, for the business of the District of Columbia—but failed by a vote of 96 to 52—not two thirds— Whittlesey called for the Reports of Standing and Select Committees, and gave notice that at 11. O’Clock he should call up the Fortification Bill— Jarvis reported from the Committee on the Public buildings, without amendment, a joint Resolution for contracting for paintings to fill the vacant spaces of the Rotundo— At 11 the Fortification bill was taken up, and debated obstinately and in very desultory manner—till the time of the recess at half past two— I procured a copy of the Bill for the admission of Arkansas into the Union, with a copy of the amendment which I had proposed copied from the Journal— Mr Abbott Lawrence invited me, to go and dine with him at his lodgings at Gadsby’s— I rode accordingly with him and Mrs Lawrence, dined with them and returned to the House at 4— The debate on the fortification Bill was resumed, and almost every amendment reported by the Committee of the whole was successively cut down; by the sixty and a hundred thousand dollars at a time.— Fort Independence in Boston Harbour was reduced from 150000 to 100000. dollars— But as it was approaching New-York, Vanderpoel moved the previous question which was carried 77 to 66— Briggs moved a reconsideration of the vote reducing the appropriation for Fort Independence but it failed— The Bill was ordered to be engrossed and read a third time to-morrow— The Bill for regulating the deposite Banks, and distributing the surplus funds among the States was passed in the Senate this afternoon to the astonishment of every body by a vote of 39 to 6. Benton, Black, Grundy, King, Walker Wright. Adjourned at 7. in the Evening.
18. IV:30. Saturday

Heat excessive: Fahrenheit at 90. At the House; a certain Coll. Hamilton of Texas was introduced to me, and made some enquiries of me concerning the boundaries between the United States and Texas, by the Treaty of Florida— I told him they were as laid down upon Mellish’s map, corrected to the 1st. of January 1818— Jarvis obtained leave to introduce a Bill for supplementary appropriations for the navy Department—twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union.—
19. IV:30. Sunday.

This was one of those days of intense heat, which disqualify me for all active exertion. I attended alone the morning and afternoon service at the Presbyterian Church— There was none at St. John’s— Mr Elliot’s morning text was from Numbers 10–29. [“]And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Raguel the Midianite, Moses father in Law, We are journeying unto the place of which the Lord said, I will give it you: come thou with us, and we will do thee good; for the Lord hath spoken good concerning Israel”— There was something out of the line of Presbyterian commonplaces in this text— The account of Hobab’s connection with Moses and the Israelites is one of the episodical details of the Exodus from Egypt— It is one of those minute occurrences which accredit that most wonderful event one of the numerous internal evidences of the truth of the History, which after all so heavily taxes human belief— The afternoon text was from Matthew 5.14. “Ye are the light of the world.”— Mr Elliot composes and reads his Sermons; which are accordingly sensible and rational discourses, without enthusiasm, and without movements of fervid eloquence— From the tenour of his morning prayer, it appeared that the church was yet upon the lookout for a pastor— There was a light thunder shower this afternoon, while we were at Church, and the air of the Evening was fresher, though still oppressively sultry— I have agreed to give John Wilson and his wife 25 dollars a month from this day forward— Their wages have been hitherto 20— I have been some days occupied in preparing my Report of the proceedings in Committee of the whole, and in the House upon my proposed amendment to the Bill for admitting the State of Arkansas into the Union— My correspondence consequently falls into arrears again. My Speech on the rations, comes back with echoes of thundering vituperation from the South and West, and with one universal shout of applause from the North and East— This is a cause upon which I am entering at the last Stage of Life, and with the certainty that I cannot advance in it far— My Career must close leaving the cause at the threshold— To open the way for others, is all that I can do. The cause is good and great.
20. IV. Monday.

I called this morning on Mr William Otis at the Prison, where he had his memorial to Congress all prepared— He wished me to present it, and get it referred to a Select Committee with power to send for persons and papers, and to sit during the recess of Congress: which I told him it would be impossible to obtain. I promised him however to present his Memorial, and to move its reference to a select Committee; but I presumed the House would refer it to the Committee of Claims— Immediately after the Journal was read I asked the consent of the House to present the Memorial—the Speaker said he was about to call the States for Petitions— I acquiesced— He began with Maine whence two or three petitions were presented from Maine and referred. Lane of Indiana moved the suspension of the rules to take up the Deposite and distribution Bill from the Senate— There was much writhing under this, and a desperate struggle to separate the two Bills, but it failed by a vote of 120 to 96— The whole Bill was referred and made the special order for to-morrow at 12. and every day till disposed of. Hiram P. Hunt offered a Resolution for a Select Committee to enquire whether members of Congress had been accommodated with loans of money from Banks for the purpose of Speculation in the public lands— I opposed this Resolution, but it passed. Wise moved a suspension of the Rules to take up Dromgoole’s deposite Bank enquiry with his amendment 110 to 57. lost for want of two thirds— Recess from 2:30 to 4— Spent it in the Room of the Committee of Manufactures— After dinner I offered a Resolution to print 1000 copies of the Constitutions of all the States for the use of the House—but it failed 57 to 66— The Bill for altering the course of the Cumberland road was rejected at the third reading 88 to 76. Adjourned about Sunset. Walk home with Jarvis— Mrs Wilson very ill with cramps and fever. Dr Huntt here— T. J. Frye— Sultry evening— Light thunder gust and rain.
21. IV. Tuesday

I was still somewhat indisposed— Mr Hassler called upon me with a new Statement of his grievances and his squabbles with the Secretary of the Treasury about his compensation for his labours on the Coast Survey— It has been referred to the Committee of the House upon Commerce for some act of Legislation; which they are unwilling to propose— Hassler says he must throw up the whole concern, if they deny him his compensation and all his contingencies— At the House a motion from the Committee on the District of Columbia to suspend the Rules for a Resolution to take up Bills relating to the District next Saturday, finally succeeded by a vote of more than two thirds, and the Resolution was adopted— Attempts were made to obtain special Assignments for sundry other Bills which failed. M’Kay offered again his new Tariff Resolutions—and by a vote of to just failed of the two thirds necessary to suspend the Rules. He gave notice that he should offer the same Resolutions again and if he should again fail he would offer a Resolution for an Amendment to the Constitution, to distribute among the States the surplus funds now in the Treasury— At Noon the Order of the day— The House went into Committee of the Whole on the Union upon the Bill to regulate the Public Deposites, Sutherland in the Chair—debated until the recess, sundry amendments were offered and rejected— One by Anthony to the eleventh Section—an out of door compromise, adopted before it was offered— I was about to offer, a few useless words against it when the recess came, which I passed in the Room of the Committee of Manufactures— John Ross the Chief of the Cherokees called me out and asked me to present their Memorial against the mock Treaty to the House— After the Recess Anthony’s Amendment was debated and adopted; the Bill was reported to the House; and by the Previous Question passed to the third reading 163 to 44. and then passed 155 to 38. Adjourned near 9 O’Clock in the Evening. Jarvis rode home with me, and told me that Anthony’s amendment was in Donelson’s hand-writing— He said the Administration party was entirely broken up; which I doubt.
22. IV:15. Wednesday

Meeting of the Committee of manufactures at 9— Present Adams, Denny Dickerson, Judson M’Comas, Webster, absent Granger, Holsey and Lee— Senate Bill 143 to authorize Daniel Tyler to import an iron canal passage boat in detached parts—& free of duty— I was directed to report without amendment, and that it ought not to pass— Senate Bill 285 about railway spikes, nails and pins, I was directed to report without amendment and to urge its passage— Mr Judson was authorised to postpone his report upon silk—and I was authorised to move at my discretion that the Committee be discharged from further consideration of all the subjects referred to them— In the House, immediately after the Journal was read I asked the consent of the House to present the Memorial and Protest of the Cherokee Representatives against the Ratification, Confirmation and execution of the Treaty of New Echota of 3. Decr 1835—the Memorial was received, ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Sutherland moved that the Harbour Bill should be made the special order of this and the following days, after 12 O’Clock till disposed of—several members proposed other Bills and Cambreleng proposed the Bill making appropriations for the execution of certain Indian Treaties, and called the yeas and nays— The Bill was added and the resolution was adopted— The Land Bill was taken up, and laid on the table by yeas and naysThe House went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, L. Lincoln in the Chair, on the Harbour Bill—which was debated till the recess, when I went to Gadsby’s with Mr and Mrs. Abbott Lawrence, and dined with them— Mr Saml. P. Gardner of Boston also dined with them— At 4. we returned to the House, and resumed the debate— Idle discussion between Wise, Balie Peyton, and Mann of New-York, about the Deposite Bill and Anthony’s amendment— Vinton finally moved an increase of an appropriation for removing obstructions in the Ohio river— The Bill was laid aside; the Committee rose, and the House adjourned between 8 and 9.— Walk home with Jarvis, Mr John Cramer of New-York shewed me a Letter from his Son, William Cramer at the New-York University, and asked me to send him a copy of my rations Speech—Care of E. Curtis—which I did— Mr John Connell was here this Evening.
23. IV:30. Thursday

Rainy Night and Morning— Call at the Bank of the Metropolis— At the House— Reports of Committees were received. I reported from the Committee of Manufactures the Bill from the Senate 143. without amendment; with a recommendation that the Bill do not pass—referred to the Committee of the whole, and made the order of the day to-morrow. I reported also the Senate Bill 285. about Spikes and iron pins, without amendment, and moved to consider the Bill now. it did accordingly pass the second and third reading immediately. Gillett attempted to get up his Bill for a gold coinage of one, two and three dollar pieces, but failed for want of the two thirds— The Amendments of the Senate to the Bill from the House for reorganizing the General Post-Office were taken up and debated till past Noon, when the Orders of the day were called— House went into Committee of the whole on the Union L. Lincoln in the Chair— Vinton moved a reconsideration of vote passed yesterday, upon which followed a debate of two hours upon the Ohio river— Then the new Harbour Bill was taken up and John Bell, moved to strike out the enacting clause— He spoke about an hour till the recess— I went with Mr Granger to his lodgings at Gadsby’s and dined with him— Matthew L. Davis came in after dinner, and spoke again about Letters to Alexander Hamilton and to my father about a plan for an invasion of Mexico, which was approved by the British administration of William Pitt— At four I returned with Mr Granger to the House of Representatives; the Chairman of the Committee of the whole on the Union had just resumed the Chair, and Mr Bell in about five hours conducted his Speech about the Harbour Bill, and against Executive Patronage, Presidential interference with Elections, and in reply to a Speech of Towne of Georgia some weeks ago. Then Mercer made a short Speech, and between 9 and 10 at Night the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— Jarvis rode home with me— Yesterday a Son of F. S. Key was killed in a duel, by another Midshipman named Sherburne.
24. V:30. Friday

Mr Jagger called on me this morning with further enquiries, respecting the British West-India Colonial Trade.— He is a very illiterate, ignorant person, yet he is determined to publish a pamphlet upon this very intricate and complicated subject— A Woman came also with a list of tickets for a raffle, for a carriage— At the House, reports were received from Committees— A Bill from the Senate annulling certain Bank creations by the territorial Legislature of Florida, which passed 2d. and third readings— W. B. Shepard Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, moved to take up a Bill from the Senate for rechartering the Banks in the District of Columbia; which was opposed by F. Thomas, chairman of the select Committee on the District Banks, who has reported a Bill to recharter the Banks till the 3d. of March 1837.— This run into a debate till Noon when the special order of the day was called— M’Kay for the third time moved a suspension of the Rules for him to offer three resolutions looking to the reduction of the revenue both from imposts and from the Sales of Lands—124 to 66. after a call of the House— M Kay gave notice that he would offer the same Resolutions again next Monday— The Harbour Bill came up again and Vinton moved an additional appropriation for Maumee river— Patton commenced a set Speech against the whole system of appropriations for harbours— Recess at half past two.— I passed it in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and in the Library— I saw in the House this morning Mr Samuel P. Carson, Secretary of State of the new Texian Republic—and Mr Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Solomon Lincoln of Hingham— At four, the Session was resumed and the Harbour Bill was debated till past ten in the Evening when the Committee was compelled to rise, and the House to adjourn from mere inability to keep a Quorum. Wise and Balie Peyton, wasted hours in the idle proposals of amendment, and sarcastic and petulant Speeches— Jarvis rode home with me in the rain— Fire in our dining room— My wife and Mary both unwell.
25. V. Saturday

I called this morning at D. Clagett’s shop and settled an account there—then at the Patent Office, and found the Superintendent H. L. Ellsworth, quite unwell— I went to enquire about the Patent of a Drawing knife for Edmund Richards— I was told it was ready for the signature of the Attorney General, and would be sent to me when ready— Then at Brown’s Hotel, where I left a card and a note for Mr John Pope—and lastly at Mrs Peyton’s where were Mr and Mrs Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth— At half past ten I found the house in Session in Committee of the whole. G. Loyall in the Chair, upon Bills relating to the District of Columbia. Several of these were passed with little discussion, but with some light skirmishing on the Washington Monument Bill— The joint-Resolution from the Senate concerning the Smithsonian bequest had been referred to this Committee, and made part of this order this morning at the motion of F. Thomas— When it was taken up, I moved the Bill from our select Committee as an amendment; and it was adopted, reported passed to a third reading, and passed without opposition. Howard asked the reason for the large bond required of the agent by the Bill which I gave him, and he acquiesced. Patton shewed signs of opposition, but made none. Hamer of Ohio asked for the yeas and nays to record his name against the Bill, but the House refused them and passed the Bill with less than ten negative votes— I went into the Senate and explained to B. W. Leigh, the Chairman of the Senatorial Committee, the reason of the change from a joint Resolution to a Bill; and for requiring a bond of the agent. He approved the change to the Bill, but expressed doubts as to the expediency of requiring the Bond— At one O’Clock the House went again into Committee of the whole on the Harbour Bill, L. Lincoln in the Chair—recess at 1/2 past 2. I passed the time in the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and the Library— Resumed the Harbour Bill followed by the Light-House Bill— Committee rose for want of a Quorum before 9. Adjourned— Walk home with Jarvis.
26. V:30 Sunday

I was unwell in the Night and forced to leap from my bed, for the cramp in my left leg, which however I escaped— Copious rain almost all night and with little intermission throughout this day— Fire in our dining room— St. John’s Church was opened after an interval of five weeks for making repairs— I went over, and found there only Mr Hawley with five men, apparently of the workmen. I then went to the Presbyterian Church, and found Mr Elliot making a short prayer, with four men for his whole auditory— There was no other service, and I came home— Mr John Pope, late Governor of the Territory of Arkansas, and before and since a Citizen of Kentucky, dined with us, together with Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith— Mr and Mrs Frye were also invited to come, but were deterred probably by the heavy-rain Mr Pope remained with us till past nine in the Evening— In the years 1807 and 8. I sat with him in the Senate of the United States. He was then from Kentucky in the prime of life, and the full tide of popularity; though he had then lost his right arm— In 1810, while we were in Russia, he married my wife’s Sister Eliza Johnson, by whom he had two beautiful daughters— They are all dead— The youngest daughter was married, and died within a year or two leaving an infant Son and daughter— Pope was long the rival and competitor of H. Clay in Kentucky, and finally overshadowed by his superior influence and talents Pope then betook himself to Jacksonism; contributed much to secure to Jackson the electoral vote of that State in 1828. He was scantily rewarded by the Government of the Territory of Arkansas, from which about two years since he was extruded, and returned to Kentucky— He is now almost broken-hearted with political disappointment, and private calamity in the loss of his children;—and talks of going to settle in Texas.— He struggled however to be and was cheerful.
27. V:45. Monday

Restless and anxious Night— Letter received from S. Sampson to Jacob H Loud—left it at Mrs Peyton’s— Saw him afterwards at the house— Saw there also Mr N. Biddle, President of the Bank of the United States— Petitions were called for, but there were scarcely any to be offered— Bell of Tennessee presented a Memorial from Nashville, for the acknowledgement of the Independence of Texas, and moved suspension of the Rules to offer a Resolution for an appropriation for a Minister to the Republic of Texas— Mann of New-York moved once and twice to lay the Resolution and Memorial on the Table carried by yeas and nays 142 to 54— Vinton offered a joint Resolution by which Bills passed in one house at one Session of Congress may be taken up and passed by the other house at the next Session, of the same Congress—which non obstante my earnest remonstrances was by acclamation and the previous question carried— M’Kay for the third time moved to suspend the Rules for his Anti-tariff Resolutions—very nearly carried 127 to 74. Not two thirds— They will certainly pass before the close of the Session— Order of the day Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— L. Lincoln in the Chair— Continuation of the Cumberland Road in Ohio, Indiana and Illinois—debate resumed on Mercer’s Amendment to turn it contingently into a Rail-road—lost— Recess at 1/2 past two— Room of the Committee of Manufactures— Sitting resumed. Bill of Appropriations for certain Indian Treaties— I caused the Memorial of the Cherokee Chiefs against the Treaty to be read—wincing of Cambreleng and Howard—warm debate. Fury of the Georgians Owens and Haynes— Attempts to suppress the reading— Wise moves and carries a call upon the President for the documents. Mann moves to lay on the table—lost 99 to 37. at least 60 did not answer— Committee rose, and reported the other Bills, at my motion. Adjourned about 9.— Jarvis rode home with me—
28. V:30. Tuesday.

Call at Gadsby’s and left a card for N. Biddle and at Mrs Peyton’s and left a Letter to Jacob H. Loud. The children rode with me to the Capitol— At the House, a Message was received from the President, with the printed documents in answer to the call of last Evening from the House concerning the Cherokee Treaty— The Message and Report from the Secretary of War were ordered to be printed— Sundry Reports from Committees were received; among which a Bill from the Committee of ways and means appropriating two Millions four hundred thousand dollars more for the suppression of Indian hostilities— Joseph R. Ingersoll brought up his Resolution for distributing books among the new members of Congress and carried it with a proviso that it should not authorise any reprint— Cave Johnson moved to suspend the rules to offer a Resolution of enquiry whether members had sold their books, and what they had cost since 1830. lost by yeas and nays 106 to 70. At one, the special order of the day—the first Harbour Bill reported from the Committee of the whole last Evening— Sundry Amendments proposed and lost— Previous question upon engrossment carried— Hawes moved to recommit the Bill with Instructions to strike out the appropriation for Hudson river— Lost by yeas and nays— Recess at 1/2 past 2. Room of the Committee of Manufactures, Back of the Pillars I met Lewis Marshall, brother of the late Chief Justice whom I had seen at Amsterdam in June 1797. and not since—39 years— He remarked the ravages of time, on my countenance— I had no trace of recollection of his though well remembering him— He is and has been many years a resident of Kentucky— After the recess the Harbour, Light-House and Cumberland Road Bills were debated till near ten O’Clock and were carried— Sharp skirmish between Hawes who made a Speech of two hours against the Harbour Bill, and Sutherland Chairman of the Committee of Commerce who reported it. Sutherland succeeded— Evening conversation with N. Biddle, by the Pillars outside the Bar. Home at 11.
29. V:15. Wednesday

These persons came to obtain for me a certificate and recommendation of a mode of renovating featherbeds, which I declined, but agreed to pay for the experiment made gratuitously last week with some of our own beds— The children rode with me to the Capitol— For the morning hours the amendments of the Senate to the Bill for the re-organization of the Post-Office, which had been reported by the Committee of the whole were taken up in the House; some of them had been adopted and some disagreed to by the House but as soon as the debate upon them began in the House the previous Question was moved and carried.— This became a question upon the whole; which was however again divided—the yeas and nays were twice taken; but it had all been settled out of the house and all the amendments of the Senate were adopted— Those of the annual Post-Office Bill were agreed to without opposition— Briggs from the Committee of Enrolled Bills asked leave to offer a Bill to alter the time of the Annual Meeting of Congress to the first Monday in November— The rules were suspended—the Resolution passed; the Bill presented twice read and the question of engrossment came by overwhelming majorities without allowing the yeas and nays to be taken— On the engrossment they just made out to get the call of yeas and nays—and they were 99 to 93. I moved the Commitment of the Bill, with Instructions to amend it so as to be only a Bill for the next annual Meeting of Congress— Miller opposed this. the previous question was called and the Bill passed 101 to 95.— The Bill to continue the Cumberland Road, was debated till the recess. I dined with Mr A Lawrence— Mr Josiah Bradley of Boston was there and left, immediately after dinner for home— Evening Session debate on the continuation of the Cumberland Road Bill, previous Question twice called— Carried the second time and the Bill was passed— The Indian Treaty Appropriation Bill then came up, and my motion to strike out the Cherokee Treaty appropriations was debated till Midnight, when the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Jarvis rode home with me— Just before the adjournment J. M. Patton told me that Mr Madison was dead.
30. VI. Thursday

The children rode with me to the Capitol— Met in the Committee room of the joint Library Committee, the joint Committee for furnishing the Rotundo with four historical Paintings— The Committee of the Senate, consists of Messrs. Preston, of S.C. Wall of New-Jersey and Wright of New-York. Mr Preston only of the Senate Committee was present— The Committee of the House, are Jarvis, Adams, M’Keon, Henry Johnson and Howard, who was absent— The rest all present— There was some conversation, and the names of Alston, Sully, Vanderlyn, Rembrandt Peale, Inman, Chapman and Morse were mentioned and discussed with reference to the selection of an Artist. I moved that Allston should at once be engaged for two of the Pictures; which was approved by all present except M’Keon— The Committee agreed to meet again to-morrow morning at nine— I found the house in Session; about to take the yeas on a motion of M’Carty to suspend the Rules for a Resolution of Instruction to the Secretary of War, for carrying on the continuance of the Cumberland Road. It failed— Then Sundry Bills at the third reading were taken up and passed.
